markdownRemark.html:
Simple → Complex is the dimension that describes how irregular and interconnected is a system. Simple systems can be broken down into smaller pieces that are understandable in isolation. If you make changes to a small subset of the system, you don’t have to fear unexpected ramifications in parts not directly connected to what you’re operating on. Complex systems are the exact opposite: you’ll need to keep in mind a lot of things and thread carefully.

Easy → Hard is the dimension of how much effort it takes to understand and successfully execute something. Easy things can be explained in a few sentences and even if it’s something that you’ve never done before, you’ll probably be fine. By definition, normally you can’t get hard stuff right at first try.

It goes without saying that complex stuff tends to be hard, while simple stuff tends to be easy, but that’s not always the case. Software engineering can shift this balance almost alchemically, although not always for the best.

Building abstractions

Every time you build an abstraction, you encapsulate a given amount of complexity, making it easier to use. When you print to the console you’re probably doing it in a single line of code: that’s an abstraction over a whole lot of subsystems that you might not even know about. It’s easier to print that way, but the complexity is still there, hidden behind a single function call.

So what’s the point of abstracting?

While in the previous example abstracting did not decrease complexity, it did draw a box around a sub-system. If you remember, simple systems are made up of smaller boxes, so abstraction is a step towards composing bigger systems without increasing complexity. It’s also good that it made things easier: if it took 100 lines of code to print something to a console, we would be years behind compared to where we are today, just because of all the economic implications.

This is why we don’t write everything in assembly: both because it’s easier (more economical) to write in higher-level languages, and because function calls, for loops and other flow control structures proved to be good abstractions over machine-level operations. Keep in mind: none of these things simplifies the resulting assembly code, but they do actively prevent it from exploding in terms of complexity, all the while allowing us to produce more of it.

Not all abstraction manages complexity

Abstraction is sometimes introduced just to make things easier. An example would be when you’re introducing a new interface with the sole goal of making it easier to swap in and out a replacement for a component. It will take you less effort to change the affected references, but the box that you just drew is a second layer around a pre-existing block (i.e. the concrete class). Explicitly declaring an interface also makes it easier to enforce a public contract, but there is no real complexity management happening in this case. Dependency injection is another example of this.

Trading simplicity for ease of use

The right amount of complexity

Every problem has its own natural level of complexity. Writing a physics engine for a 3D videogame is going to be more complicated than writing a webpage with a form in it. You can’t escape from that. It’s also true that this is a lower-bound limit: you can definitely overcomplicate any solution and increase complexity up to almost any level.

Oversimplification too tends to have the same effect because the original simplistic solution won’t solve the problem in a satisfactory way and, if you don’t realize that your initial approach is flawed, then your only course of action will be to add more complexity on top. A text-book example of oversimplification is trying to parse HTML files using regular expressions.

The simplest solution is the one with the right amount of complexity.

The right amount of difficulty

Simple and hard

Simple and Easy

Simple and easy are two somewhat correlated but different concepts. It’s also the same with complex and hard, but software engineering can shift the balance in any given project by

Simple → Complex and Easy → Hard are two different dimensions with a positive correlation coefficient. You would expect to encounter in the wild samples from the whole spectrum, but especially in the context of software engineering, we love to overcomplicate things, skewing the distribution and making it progressively harder to experience simplicity, too often mistaken for ease of use.

While the two dimensions are indeed correlated, the practice of software engineering can easily shift the balance in any given project. Unfortunately, there are limits in how much you can improve something, with virtually none in the opposite direction.
